review_title: Research Coordinator Position at Northshore C: Pros and Cons Review
pros: Exciting research opportunities: As a research coordinator at Northshore C, you'll have access to various research projects in various fields. This position offers the chance to contribute to cutting-edge advancements and make a meaningful impact. Collaborative environment: Northshore C fosters a collaborative work culture, providing ample opportunities to collaborate with renowned researchers, scientists, and experts. You'll have the chance to work alongside talented individuals passionate about research. Skill development: The research coordinator position at Northshore C offers significant opportunities for professional growth. You'll gain valuable experience in project management, data analysis, grant writing, and research methodologies, enhancing your skillset for future career prospects. Networking opportunities: Working at Northshore opens doors to a vast network of professionals and experts in the research community. You'll have the chance to establish connections that benefit personal and professional growth.
cons: High-pressure environment: Research coordination can be demanding, requiring you to meet deadlines, handle multiple projects simultaneously, and manage various stakeholders. This position may involve high-pressure situations, which can be stressful for some individuals. Long working hours: Research coordination often involves long working hours, especially during critical project phases or when facing imminent deadlines. Preparing for extended workdays and potential work on weekends or evenings is essential. Administrative tasks: As a research coordinator, you'll handle administrative tasks, such as budget management, documentation, and report writing. While these tasks are essential, they may detract from direct research involvement.

review_title: Stagnant wage growth, difficult upward mobility
job_title: Outpatient Physical Therapist II in Skokie, IL
pros: Good support working at a large outpatient clinic in Skokie. Low work expectations, easy job. Great coworkers, great clinic manager.
cons: Extremely low starting salary as a new grad, and extremely slow wage growth. No effort to keep young talent in terms of matching higher offers found elsewhere, lots of turnover. Northshore is resistant to market adjustments for salaries, meaning someone hired today, will be hired in at a higher salary than employees who have been there for years with the same experience level. HR is resistant to current trends in outpatient salaries at other similar institutions such as Northwestern or Shirley Ryan, who are paying significant higher salaries. Ever since COVID19 pandemic, benefits were cut, such as our annual continuing education credit, which has never been returned to the previous level. In general, Northshore appears uninterested in investing in physical therapy, despite its recent growth across the Chicagoland area with doctors offices and immediate cares opening up, all devoid of physical therapy services.

review_title: Not a great place for APPs or innovation
pros: It’s well funded—you’ll not want for any material resource. Technology department is excellent and EMR is well maintained. Clinical staff are capable, kind and dedicated. Medical care really is outstanding, despite other criticisms.
cons: Upper management has been replaced in the last decade and may bring with it some change eventually but middle management has not and it’s a drag on the system. Very top-down decision making at most levels in a large system where often times managers/administrators cannot be aware of intricacies of the issues. When there is an issue a manager fails to respond to there is no successful way to navigate around them and get assistance. Employees are not evaluated by people with direct knowledge of their performance and productive feedback is not a value of the system—it fails to provide critical feedback for professional development. No attention is given to employee retention, even when the employee is excellent and losing them will hurt the team; conversely, poor quality employees are generally let to fester b/c middle management is not competently trained to manage. The system is very responsive to technology issues but ignores employee issues. On the clinical side, nursing and APPs are generally greatly restricted in their practice with almost all decision-making falling to physician staff. In an extremely short-sighted move the system destroyed its social work department in a half completed project and the fallout has echoed through the system and reduced the quality of support that can be offered. Clinical decision making is impacted by the fact that in a tough spot clinicians have felt the lack of support from management.

pros: Good benefits and interesting work, especially if you have not previously been exposed to the health industry.
cons:
This was a toxic work environment and my concerns fell on my boss' deaf ears for over a year. I am a person who strives for a high level of achievement and morality in my own business conduct. Speaking out was continuous and difficult and, for a long time, yielded no action. 

Finally, when my concerns were "heard", I was gaslit and forced to report to my colleague at the center of most of my concerns. Work was withheld from me, I was spoken to in a way that was demeaning and belittling (on multiple occasions), I was physically confronted and cornered by a co-worker, and punished for having interests beyond work (this involved probing questions such as "Do you even want to work here?").

Though there were bright spots, my experience at NorthShore University HealthSystem Foundation was negative. Upper management does not support their employees and does not listen to their concerns. Should you have any concerns, the company will do anything it can to get rid of you without firing you. Do not seek out a job with the Foundation.

review_title: Negatives far outweigh the few positives
pros:
403(b) plan has good investment options
There is a pension
Good place to coast if you land a nice position, minimal effort required 
IT has been remote since Covid started
cons:
These are IT department specific:
* Pay is below market rates for similar roles
* Raises are NOT performance based and cap at 5%, it is a zero sum event.  A leader has a fixed pool of $ to spread around to all of their reports, meaning team members that slack are likely getting the same raise as someone else who is busting their hump.
* Nearly impossible to terminate poor performers, makes a great place to land a position and coast without fear of consequences
* Terrible place for entry level grunt work, little room for advancement or learning
* Have merged with 3 other hospitals but the department head count has actually gone DOWN, fewer people, more work.
* Escalatory office, be ready to have people run to upper management if they don't get their way
* Slow organization, do not expect anything to get done quickly here (unless they escalate, see above)
* Siloed and poor communication between the two halves of IT, not all teams work well with others

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Skokie, IL
pros: The salary is above average.  Benefits are good.  Free parking, and free shuttle bus to Metra.  If you're a mediocre employee, you will love working at NorthShore, especially in the I.T. department.  If you excel, you'll hate it.  You will never be challenged, and your skills will never grow.  You'll soon get bored and quit.
cons: Management embarked on an "employee engagement" program about two years ago.  I have yet to see even one tangible outcome from it.  They talk about it constantly ("we're working hard to gather your feedback"..."we're formulating a strategy"...), but it's all just talk.  They also launched a "customer loyalty" initiative which has driven away most of the talent.  Employee reviews are no longer based on competency, productivity, knowledge, and skill.  They're based on "service values".  What are service values?  In the I.T. department, it boils down to this: smile, placate the user, and then call the software vendor.  Don't bother knowing anything about your own product because management won't trust your judgment anyway.  Managers greatly frown upon anyone who makes waves.  I know one employee who got put on a "performance improvement plan" because she complained about something during one of management's own "employee engagement" feedback meetings!

After my orientation I realized that  I was working with extremely immature individuals and it's sad to say but extremely racist.  Yes! This highly praised organization does very little to combat discrimination.  Some groups of people are promoted, rarely work holidays, get scheduled to their preference. I have heard nurses reprimand staff in front in public and even talk about patients openly. 
They talk in there foreign language and its very uncomfortable feeling. 
The same people receive praise and recognition repeatedly while others stand in the shadows even when they work harder.

Housekeeping is under valued and it is simply because they are not seen as people. 

This environment is very unhealthy.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Skokie, IL
pros: Good coworkers, everyone cares about everyone, health/well being is number one priority, new ceo seems like he’s on a good strategic path
cons: To start off, managment main goal is to work against you. Feedback is garbage, not related to your job and it feel like high school where everyone is talking about everyone behind their backs. Managers always trying to get someone to talk and rat others out. You get appraised for being the teachers pet and doing what managers want, even though it may not be ethical, professional or even respectful. Managers are Extremely biased and prejudice toward certain people. Absolutely no advancement to entry level employees. Company is expanding and new medical groups are opening, yet turn over rate and retention is humiliating. Too much focus on external customers than internal employees. So many promotional opportunities happening for higher ups (VPs, directors, managers), yet coordinators and entry level roles stay in position for 3-5 years and never receive an advancement opportunity. Half of the time, everyone leaves for better opportunity and the same cycle starts all over again. The company benefits are great, but you don’t earn nothing and you sit and watch other people move up in their career while you answer phone calls and emails for years.

review_title: Fast paced culture; Inept leadership; Cost cutting & layoffs
pros: Culture is centered on service values where 49% of an employee's review is measured.  This means everyone smile, placate and be nice.  Vacation, sick time and flexible work arrangements are generous.  Pay is good.  Good work/life balance.  Nice co-workers.
cons: For medical insurance, NorthShore is self-insured - good if you use the NorthShore System.  Promotions are not always based on work/talent but on relationships.  Leadership seems behind the ball and overreacts to issues in the market.  This has occurred by laying off 1% of the workforce today based on a five year revenue projection. Many workers are looking for leaders with vision/direction, but few are found.

pros: Training on electronic medical records.  Average salary.  They promise you the world before you are hired.  Once hired, all bets are off and everything changes.  Even senior management is less than truthful.  Very youth oriented environment, from physicians to support staff.  (Not so great if you are experienced or over 40. ).  Northshore likes to take people who are fresh and inexperienced, and mold them to NorthShore's liking.
cons: Management more interested in numbers and making the upper echelons of the hierarchy happy, at the expense of some darn good, loyal and professional workers..They also tend to delegate responsibilities  that they should be doing themselves.  Young managers (2 in particular) are insecure with older, professional and more experienced employees, so they tend to play the 'power card'. review_title: Firm hierarchy but co-workers are like family
pros:
Co-workers are like family, creating a close-knit group that's able to support each other through thick and thin. 

The ability to learn and grow is prevalent, which prepares you for the next job. 

Leadership knows when to funnel-down negative reviews and senior management knows how to funnel up praise.

Annual cost of living increases are great. 

I found the performance reviews to help me grow as an employee and found that my supervisors gave me great feedback. NorthShore's mantra of "we won't bombard you with negative comments; that should be brought up in weekly meetings" is held true. 

Even though the service value awards can seem a bit chotskie-ish, it's a nice system of letting a co-worker know that you've seen them go above and beyond and that they appreciate the work that you're doing. An added bonus is that they award monetary leadership awards for truly excelling. 

There's a lot of good management at NorthShore who are able to see the potential in their employees and help them grow. Whenever I made a mistake, my supervisor was always gentle and gracious with me, working with me to learn instead of shaming me and complaining to leadership. 

During my time there, my partner underwent a major health crisis. Although he wasn't treated at NorthShore, the department I worked in, including senior management, really worked with me so that I could be there with him over the course of his treatment. The Executive Director of the department even sent me a text when he found out of my partner's diagnosis to give me support. That was so very appreciated, as was the entire offices warm wishes. 

NorthShore has service values that employees are to uphold at all times. On first hearing of this, it seems like we should all do a big eye roll. But NorthShore has everyone, from top down, adhere to the service values, which makes a big difference in the culture. It's so nice to see leadership employ service values, too. 

Everyone knows each other so well at NorthShore (or at least the department I worked in) that when working on a project, a manager would approach me and give me helpful advice on how to approach the project and ultimately, how to present it.
cons:
Some people are put on the fast track and can be promoted endlessly while others are put on the slow road. Because compensation could be better, this results in talent looking outside the organization. Because some are put on the fast-track, some hold leadership positions when they're clearly not qualified or clearly do not like or want their job. 

Sometimes it's frustrating trying to advance your career because when there's a chance for promotions, it can seem like they're going to those on the fast-track. 

Appearances matter at NorthShore. Sometimes the appearance matters more than the substance, which can be aggravating. 

I worked in a really small department of less than 20 people, and we worked offsite. This really helped in the family dynamic feel, but could feel ridiculous when the management team would meet about projects. It felt too top heavy. Ultimately, projects would come down the pipeline and lower-level staff would be pulling most of the weight, but wouldn't be pulled into the conversation with senior management, who, many times, were told to be hush hush about projects. In such a small office, that really tends to erode employee morale. 

The top down model at NorthShore has some cons. Sometimes it felt aggravating not being able to go directly to the ED or AVP for simple edits. Instead, it felt silly having to through a manager, who then went through the Executive Assistant, who went to the ED.

pros: Nice environment. Good Nursing Educators!!

If they find out that you are trying hard to go higher, they will do everything they can to become obstacle for you. In addition, when time comes to annual employee review, regardless of whether you work hard or not, they will always minimize you. There is not a good team work between RNs and PCTs at all. If you work as a PCT,  you are on your own. Nurses do not want to bother themselves to help you. They will all tell you "That is your job."

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Skokie, IL
pros: NOTHING! Absolutely nothing!!! I've been sitting here and thinking because I needs 20 word minimum but I honestly have nothing. Please just go to cons, because that's all this company is!
cons:
I have no idea where to start!! 

1. There is no such thing as sick days, when call in sick, you get written up.

2. They make you work 9 1/2 hours a days, starting this month (2/2015) you only get 45 minutes lunch and only 20 minute break. They will tell you when you can take your break. Oh and if you get thirsty, you cant get up to go get water because your on the clock. Its just beyond ridiculous.

3. Micromanagement beyond the regular. These managers breath down your neck so hard that you actually feel the hot breath touching your back.

4. They can careless about their employees, for example: There is a huge empty parking lot in front of the building. In that area, its only Northshore employees but they still don't want you to park there. If you do, they will tow you... Seriously? NO ONE ELSE PARKS THERE, why can't your employees park in the front during the winter?

5. You can almost never request a day off, the managers there (the ones that think thy are doing big things) will most likely deny it. They are all about "policies" that don't even exist. 

6. When you start your day with this ridiculous phone system they have going, you log in and BOOM - automatically you are live and the caller is in your ear, there is no such thing as answering the call, it just pops up and your live even if your not ready yet. Once your done with the call, status bar blinks for 30 seconds. When that 30 seconds is over, your live on the next call. If your not, you'll be in trouble sitting at the annoying managers desks because you went over "Wrap" time.

7. My list can go to maybe the #50. But i'm seriously hurting my self just thinking about Northshore Patient Access center. Its beyond ridiculous in there. I HAVE NEVER HAD A JOB THIS BAD! Any employee there will tell you the same, people are consistently leaving the company because they are just fed but with the BS. Please do yourself's a favor and skip NORTHSHORE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SYSTEMS PATIENT ACCESS CENTER!
